INTRODUCTION54

Lutzomyia (Nyssomia) intermedia (Lutz and Neiva 1912) and Lutzomyia. (Nyssomia)55

whitmani (Antunes and Coutinho 1939) are American phlebotomine sand flies and proven vectors 56

of Leishmania braziliensis (Vianna 1911), the causative agent of American Cutaneous 57

Leishmaniasis in Brazil and other South American countries (Vexenat et al. 1986, Jones et al. 1987, 58

Rangel et al. 1990, Hashiguchi et al. 1992, Salomón et al. 1995, 2001a, 2001b, Brito et al. 2002, 59

Souza et al. 2002). In some endemic areas, these two species are sympatric (Santos et al. 1993, 60

Miranda et al. 2002).   61

Sand flies are holometabolous insects with four life cycle developmental stages: egg, larva, 62

pupa and adult. Pioneer taxonomic studies of immature stages of phlebotomines used optical 63

microscopy as a common tool (Barreto 1941, Guitton and Sherlock 1969, Ward 1972). Further on, 64

Ward and Ready (1975) introduced scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to describe details of the 65

exchorionic ornamentation of the eggs of thirteen species of Brazilian phlebotomines. Thereafter, 66

other studies used SEM to reveal ultrastructural details of various immature stages of Phlebotomus67

tobbi (Adler and Theodor 1930) (Killick-Kendrick et al. 1989), and of pupae, and first and fourth 68

instars of larvae of Lu. longipalpis (Lutz and Neiva 1912) ((Leite et al. 1991, Leite and William 69

1996, 1997). Recently, Secundino and Pimenta (1999) revealed morphological characteristics of all 70

developmental stages of Lutzomyia longipalpis through SEM. Until now, only optical microscopic 71

observations have been made on the external morphology of Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani 72

(Barreto 1941). This is the first time SEM has been used to compare ultrastructural features on the 73

surfaces of their immature stages. Therefore, here we used SEM to analyze comparatively the 74

structural aspects of the external surface of the immature stages of these two sand fly vectors from 75

the same endemic area. 76

77

MATERIALS AND METHODS  78

Sand flies: Sand flies were captured at Corte de Pedra (13º 32’ South latitude and 39º 25’ West 79

longitude) in the State of Bahia, Brazil. They were then blood fed on hamsters and kept on a 50% 80



4

sugar solution ad libitum. Flies were held in colony cages and maintained at 26ºC with 60% 81

humidity to allow breeding. Three to four days after the blood meal, females were allowed to lay 82

eggs, which hatched after 3 to 4 days. The larvae were fed with the appropriate diet (Secundino and 83

Pimenta, 1999) in order to complete their life cycle. Twenty specimens of each developmental 84

stage, except pupae, were collected (eggs and the four larval instars), washed in phosphate buffered 85

saline (PBS) and immediately fixed overnight in 2.5% glutaraldehyde in 0.1M caccodylate buffer 86

(pH 7.2) at room temperature.  87

Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM): Fixed samples were processed for SEM as described 88

elsewhere (Secundino and Pimenta 1999). Briefly, they were post-fixed in 1% osmium tetroxide 89

(OsO4) plus 0.8% potassium ferrycianide in 0.1M caccodylate buffer (pH 7.2) and dehydrated in a 90

series of crescent ethanol concentrations. After that, the samples were critical-point dried under 91

CO2. They were then coated with a 20 nm layer of gold particles and examined under SEM (JEOL 92

JSM5600).   93

94

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION  95

Several ultrastructural details of the external surface of the immature stages of Lu. 96

intermedia and Lu. whitmani were revealed by SEM allowing us to compare the microanatomy of 97

these two important vectors.   98

The eggs of Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani are about the same size (length = 99

0.308±0.016mm and width = 0.074±0.003mm for Lu. intermedia; length = 0.307±0.010mm and 100

width = 0.077±0.002mm for Lu. whitmani), having a long oval shape and ornamentations that 101

consist of parallel ridges covering the entire exchorion (Figs. 1-4). Barreto (1941) described these 102

ridges as “connected ridges” in these same species, using optical microscopy. However, our SEM 103

observations revealed that most of these ridges are unconnected and have small tubercles between 104

them (Figs. 1 and 2). Similar observations of unconnected ridges were seen by Almeida and 105

collaborators on Lu. intermedia eggs (2004). Here, high SEM magnification revealed that these 106

ridges are formed by single lines of rounded palisade units (diameter = 0.576±0.074µ m for Lu. 107

intermedia and 0.775±0.095µ m for Lu. whitmani) that project themselves from the eggshell (high = 108

0.454±0.040µ m for Lu. intermedia and 0.597±0.043µ m for Lu. whitmani) (Figs. 3 and 4). In 109



5

contrast, Lu. longipalpis eggs present unconnected ridges formed by lines of double-rounded 110

palisade units without tubercles between them (Secundino and Pimenta 1999).  111

Some authors have speculated that exchorionic ornamentations are adaptive structures that 112

facilitate oviposition in distinct environments (Ward and Ready 1975, Perez and Ogusuku 1997). In 113

the present work, observations of the egg surfaces showed no differences in the exchorion 114

ornamentation of the two sympatric sand flies. In another study, Rogo and collaborators (1992) 115

showed intraspecific differences in the exchorions of Phlebotomus aculeatus (Lewis, Minter and 116

Ashford 1974) and Phlebotomus martini (Parrot 1936). Yet another report showed that the egg 117

exchorions of Phlelbotomus pedifer (Lewis, Mutinga and Ashford), Lu. longipalpis and Lu. 118

diabolica (Hall 1936) have similar patterns of unconnected ridges (Endris et al. 1987, Rogo et al. 119

1992, Secundino and Pimenta 1999), even though these species occur in widely separated 120

geographic areas. Others suggest, based on SEM examination of twenty-three sand fly species, that 121

exchorionic ornamentations reflect phylogenetic relationship between the species (Endris et al. 122

1987, Feliciangeli et al. 1993, Perez and Ogusuku 1997, Fausto et al. 2001). Because the exchorion 123

ornamentation is not necessarily species-specific, it seems like it cannot be used reliably as a 124

taxonomic tool. 125

 Sand fly larvae escape from the egg by breaking the shell in a manner similar to other 126

Diptera. The egg hatching of first instar larvae of Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani causes irregular 127

oblique fractures in the eggshells (Figs. 5-7 and 10). The first sign of egg hatching is an opening as 128

a door-like flap at the anterior end of the eggshell where the larva head appears (Figs. 5 and 6). 129

Following this initial event, the entire head is exposed (Figs. 6 and 7) revealing the egg buster (Fig. 130

8). It appears that the head movements, along with the friction of the egg buster, are responsible for 131

breaking the eggshell. At the same time, the distal ends of the larva caudal filaments also appear 132

outside (Figs. 7-9). These sequential events allow the larva to escape (Figs. 9 and 10). A similar 133

mechanism of egg breaking and larval escape was described for Lu. longipalpis (Leite and 134

Williams 1997, Secundino and Pimenta 1999). 135

The egg breaking in several Diptera is due to the action of a structure called egg buster 136

(synonyms: hatching spine, egg-breaker or busting teeth). Here, SEM showed the egg buster on the 137

apex of the head of Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani. The egg buster only exists on the dorsal 138

surface of the first instar larva head and has been used to differentiate the first instar from the 139



6

second instar larvae in Diptera, along with other taxonomic characters (Breland 1959, Alvan-140

Aguilar and Hamada 2003). Details of the microanatomy of the sand fly egg buster can be seen on 141

the dorsal region when the larva head is completely out of the eggshell (Fig. 19). The egg busters of 142

these two sand flies are similar structures with small differences in their dimensions (length = 143

0.027±0.003mm and width = 0.018±0.001mm for Lu. intermedia; length = 0.023±0.002mm and 144

width = 0.019±0.001mm for Lu. whitmani). The egg buster is a cuticular formation that rises from 145

the top of the larva´s head like a miniature volcanic cone (Fig. 19). Leite et al. (1997) and 146

Secundino and Pimenta (1999) observed a similar egg buster in Lu. longipalpis.147

We found Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani immatures to be very similar in aspects such 148

egg exchorionic ornamentations and egg busters, but we found some differences. For example, the 149

larva sizes differ slightly between the two species. The first instar larvae of the L. intermedia are 150

sized length = 0.467±0.09mm and width = 0.085±0.002mm; while the dimensions of the first instar 151

of Lu. whitmani are length = 0.491±0.089mm and width = 0.078±0.021mm. The fourth instar larva, 152

which represents the last larval stage, has the following dimensions for Lu. intermedia: length = 153

2.116±0.392mm and width = 0.262±0.052mm; as for dimensions of fourth instar of L. whitmani are 154

length = 2.032±0.420mm and width = 0.349±0.093mm. These size differences may not be 155

significant and probably cannot be relied upon to differentiate the two species. Moreover, larva 156

sizes are determined in part by diet, thus in the wild, the larvae of the two species may have 157

entirely different diets and sizes may vary accordingly.  Differences in sizes of laboratory-reared 158

larvae kept on the same diet may not reflect what is observed in nature. 159

 The general microanatomy revealed by SEM of the larvae of both sand fly species also 160

shows similarities between them. The bodies of both larvae are long and divided into twelve 161

segments: three thoracic and nine abdominal segments (Figs. 11-14). In both species, the larval 162

tegument is adorned dorsally and laterally with numerous setae (Figs. 11-14), which are absent on 163

the anal lobe (Figs. 15 and 16), on the head bases and on the mouthparts (Figs. 17-19). The 164

abdominal segments have prolegs (protruding elliptical structures) on its ventral side, that are used 165

for locomotion and  are not present on the first three segments nor on the anal lobe (Figs. 13, 14 166

and insets). These anatomical aspects are similar in Lu. longipalpis and Lu. bahiensis (Mangabeira 167

and Sherlock 1964) larvae (Sherlock and Carneiro 1963, Leite and William 1996, 1997, Secundino 168

and Pimenta 1999). Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani prolegs have small differences in size (length 169



7

= 0.068±0.001mm and width = 0.030±0.004mm for Lu. intermedia; length = 0.108±0.005mm and 170

width = 0.057±0.006mm for Lu. whitmani). In addition, the morphology of the anal lobe is 171

different between the species (Figs. 15 and 16). The anal lobe of Lu. whitmani is more wrinkled 172

and shorter than that of Lu. intermedia (length = 0.114±0.002mm and width = 0.123±0.003mm for 173

Lu. intermedia; length = 0.067±0.006mm and width = 0.076±0.006mm for Lu. whitmani). These 174

characteristics may comprise distinguishing features that might be useful in the bona fide175

identification of these species under SEM, further supporting ordinary adult taxonomy.  176

The larvae have well-defined, round and sclerotized head capsules  in both sandfly species 177

(Figs. 11-14 and 17-19). The mouth apparatus, consisting of clypeus, labrum, mandibles, maxillas 178

and memtum, is located in the ventral part of the head (length = 0.147±0.025mm and width = 179

0.135±0.025mm for Lu. intermedia; length = 0.092±0.032mm and width = 0.091±0.027mm for Lu. 180

whitmani) (Figs. 17-18). This type of mouth apparatus is considered as a “masticator”, as described 181

by Leite and Willians (1996, 1997) and Mukhopadway and Gosh (2000).  182

Antennal morphology is similar in Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani and changes between 183

L1 and subsequent larval instars (L2 to L4). In L1, the antennae are two-segmented with a basal 184

conical segment fused with a short ovoid distal segment that is almost as long as the basal segment 185

(Figs. 19-21). In L2 through L4, the antennae are also two-segmented but the distal segment is 186

greatly elongated (digitform) to about three times the length of the conical basal segment (Figs. 22 187

and 23). This observation differs from the initial findings of Barreto (1941), who observed 188

digitiform antennae on all larval instars of both species using optical microscopy. Recently, Pessoa 189

and collaborators (2001) described the same digitiform antennae on L4 of several sand flies. Here, 190

details of the antennae of all larval instars revealed they have three types of sensillae on the ventral 191

part and on the apex of the distal segment, independent of the change in antennal morphology from 192

L1 to L2-L4 instars (Figs. 24-30). These sensillae are important sensory organs that function as 193

hygroreceptors, contact chemoreceptors, tactile receptors, olfactory receptors and temperature 194

receptors, which enable the insects to  detect changes in the surrounding environment (Keil, 1997).  195

 We analyzed in detail all the sensilla types present on the immature stages of Lu. intermedia196

and Lu. whitmani. The classification of sensillae was made according to Hallberg and Hasson, 197

(1999) and Mitchell and collaborators (1999). There are five subtypes of trichoid sensillae which 198

were classified as: 1) long, 2) short, 3) curved long, 4) brush-like and 5) weakly brush-like. The 199



8

brush-like trichoid sensillae are localized along the dorsal and lateral parts of the larvae, but are 200

absent in the ventral parts, and behind the antennae on the top of the head (Figs. 11-14, 19, 24-25). 201

The weakly brush-like trichoid sensillae are found in the middle of the head in front of the antennae 202

(Figs. 19 and 26). The curved long trichoid sensillae are located in the lateral sides of the prolegs in 203

both species, however, they present different degrees of bending (Figs. 13, 14 and insets, and 27-204

28). The presence of curved long trichoid sensillae on the prolegs of the two studied sand flies 205

differs from what was observed in Lu. bahiensis (Sherlock and Carneiro, 1963) and in Lu. 206

longipalpis (Leite and William 1996, 1997, Secundino and Pimenta, 1999). The short trichoid 207

sensillae (0.021±0.010mm for Lu. intermedia and 0.028±0.012mm for Lu. whitmani) are observed 208

on the mouthparts (Figs. 17, 18 and 28). The long trichoid sensillae (0.066±0.011mm long for Lu. 209

intermedia and 0.068±0.022mm long for Lu. whitmani) are located in the forehead, forming a line 210

in front of the weakly brush-like trichoid sensillae (Figs. 17-19 and 28). Short trichoid sensillae and 211

long trichoid sensillae are around of the anal lobe of Lu. whitmani and in Lu. intermedia (Figs. 15 212

and 16). This type of sensillum was not found in Lu. longipalpis and Lu. bahiensis (Sherlock and 213

Carneiro, 1963, Leite and William 1996, 1997, Secundino and Pimenta 1999). Straight and curved 214

forms of long trichoid sensillae and short trichoid sensillae were previously observed by Fernandes 215

and Linardi (2002) in segment II of the mouthparts of Dermatobia hominis (Linnaeus Jr. 1781) 216

(Diptera: Oestridae). Mechanosensory sensillae with similar morphology have been found in the 217

maxillary palps of Drosophila melanogaster by Riesgo-Escovar et al (1997).  218

 Other sensillae are found on the antennae of Lu. whitmani and Lu. intermedia larvae. One 219

clavate basiconic sensillum is located in the apex of the larval antenna (Fig. 30). On the proximal 220

part of the antenna, three short blunt coeloconic sensillae are observed on the insertion of one large 221

sensillae of type multiporous clavate coeloconic sensillum (Figs. 30 and 31). Olfactory sensillae 222

with a bulbous apical dilation with pores in its wall (clavate sensillae), similar to the multiporous 223

clavate coeloconic sensillum described here, have been observed on the antennal clava of 224

Trichogramma galloi (Zucchi 1988) and T. pretiosum (Riley 1879) (Hymenoptera: 225

Trichogrammatidae), on the maxillary palps of Culicoides hollensis (Melander and Brues 1903) 226

and C. melleus (Coquillett 1901) (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae), and on the antennal funiculus of 227

Cochliomyia hominivorax (Coquerel 1858) (Diptera: Calliphoridae) (Consoli et al. 1999, Kline and 228

Axtell 1999, Fernandes et al. 2004).  229



9

Another long type of trichoid sensillae with wall pores are located on the last larval 230

segments (Fig. 32). In sand flies, these sensillae are known as caudal filaments. There are two 231

caudal filaments on L1 and four on L2 to L4. Different patterns of pores exist on the caudal 232

filaments of the two species studied. Lu. whitmani has pores situated inside the wall grooves (Fig. 233

34). In Lu. Intermedia, the grooves are not as deep as in Lu. whitmani, and the pores appear to be 234

on the surface (Fig. 33). Pessoa et al (2001) found pores on caudal filaments of larvae of Lu. 235

intermedia, Lu. whitmani, Lu. lenti (Mangabeira 1938), Lu. longipalpis and Lu. evandroi (Costa 236

Lima and Antunes 1936), but did not find any differences in the pattern of pores between the first 237

two species. Zacharuk (1985) believes that the absence of pores on the sensorial cuticle does not 238

allow chemical sensitivity, and that the presence of one single pore limits the sensitivity to taste, 239

while several pores allow the sense of olfaction. According to this author, the caudal filaments and 240

the multiporous clavate coeloconic sensillae of the first instar larvae of Lu. intermedia and Lu. 241

whitmani respond to olfactory molecules, thus are considered chemoreceptors.  242

In this study, we found mainly trichoid sensillae on the larva segments of both sandfly 243

species. Green and Hartenstein (1997) analyzed the sensillar patterns on the thoracic and abdominal 244

segments of several insect orders and described hairs and bristles (trichoid and chaetica sensillae) 245

of varied sizes and number in primitive insects and peg-like sensillae (basiconica, styloconica and 246

coeloconica) and papilla sensillae in Diptera. These authors suggested that the trichoid sensillae 247

represent mechanoreceptors that are stimulated by hair deflection. However, Zacharuk (1985) 248

claims that trichoid sensillae can have various functions including mechanical, chemical and 249

thermal reception that enable the larvae to discern changes in their environment.  Future 250

ultrastructural and electrophysiological studies will be necessary to determine the exact function of 251

these sensillae in sand flies.  Added to the results of the present work, these studies may supply 252

information about the behavior and physiology of these important vectors that might be useful for 253

the development of vector control strategies.  254

In summary, our comparative study showed that the external morphology of the eggs and 255

larvae of Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani have similar features but are distinguishable by details in 256

their microanatomy observed by SEM.  The similarities shared between these two sympatric 257

species may reflect their adaptation to similar environmental conditions.  258

Figs. 1-4. Egg surfaces of Lu. intermedia (Figs. 1 and 3) and Lu. whitmani (Figs. 2 and 4) show 407

exchorions of unconnected parallel ridges (arrowheads). High magnification images show that 408

these ridges are formed by single lines of round palisade units (asterisks). Magnifications: Fig. 1 = 409

300x, Fig. 2 = 300x, Fig. 3 = 4000x, Fig. 4 = 3000x.  410

Figs. 5-10. Sequential events of egg hatching of Lu. intermedia and Lu. whitmani. Figures 5 and 6 411

show a door-like flap at the anterior end of the eggshell (arrow), where the larva head appears. The 412

entire heads (h) are exposed outside the eggshells in figures 7 and 8. In figure 8 it is possible to 413

visualize the egg buster (arrowhead) on larva´s head and on the distal ends of the caudal filaments 414

(cf). Figures 9 and 10 show, respectively, two larvae with half and almost the entire bodies outside 415

the eggshells. Note the egg buster (arrowhead) on the larva´s head. Magnifications: Fig. 5 = 270x, 416

Fig. 6 = 330x, Fig. 7 = 230x, Fig. 8 = 550x, Fig. 9 = 230x, Fig. 10 = 190x.  417

Figs. 11-14. External morphology of Lu. intermedia (Figs. 11 and 13) and Lu. whitmani larvae 418

(Figs. 12 and 14). Lateral views of sand fly larvae (Figs. 11 and 12) show the heads (h) and the 419

caudal filaments (arrowheads). Ventral views (Figs. 13 and 14) show the larvae bodies divided into 420

twelve parts: three thorax and nine abdominal segments (white asterisks) between the head and the 421

anal lobule (black asterisks). Note the prolegs (white asterisks in figures 13 and 14) are only 422

present on the abdominal segments. Details of the prolegs and curved long trichoid sensillae 423

(circle) are seen in the two insets. The brush-like trichoid sensillae (arrows) are located in dorsal 424

and lateral parts of larva’s segments. Magnification: Fig. 11= 220x, Fig. 12 = 60x, Fig. 13 = 160x 425

and inset = 500x, Fig. 14 = 35x and inset = 250x.   426

Figs. 15 and 16. Details of the larvae´s anal lobe. In Lu. whitmani (Fig. 15) this structure is more 427

wrinkled and shorter than in Lu. intermedia (Fig. 16). Observe the crowns of short and long 428

trichoid sensillae (arrows) surrounding the base of the anal lobes. Some sensillae were accidentally 429

removed during sampling process and it is possible to see their insertions sites (arrowheads). 430

Magnifications: Fig. 15 = 500x, Fig. 16 = 400x.  431
